questions.text: Image of the side of a deceased male was given, Identify the postmortem change:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Marbling The post mortem sign shown is marbling which is an external sign of putrefaction . In marbling, the superficial veins are stained purplish red or greenish brown in a branching pattern . It is usually seen 36-48 hours after death and occurs due to the formation of sulfhemoglobin .

Highyeild:

Decomposition/putrefaction: Colour changes: The earliest sign of decomposition is greenish discoloration of the body, seen first in the right iliac fossa externally and under the liver internally ( because in caecum , the contents are more liquid and are full of bacteria.) . In these areas, It appears in 12-18 hours, and slowly spread on whole body in 24-48 hr. greenish discoloration is due to formation of Sulph meth haemoglobin. Hb→ meth Hb→ +H2S→ Sulph meth haemoglobin. Later colour may change to purple, brown, bluish green or even almost black ( colour black is due to ferric sulphide.) The colouring matter (Hb) dissociates from the B.C. and the colour is taken up by the blood vessels, which are seen as prominent lines having purple, green or brown colour, especially on shoulders, axilla & Inguinal area. This change results in 24-48 hr , and is labelled as marbling.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.Tattooing-Partly burnt/unburnt gun powder particles.Around entry wound, they are adherent to the skin. It cannot be wiped away and felt as This is called tattooing / stippling / peppering. Option B.Lividity- It is purplish blue or purplish red discoloration seen under the skin in the most superficial layers of dermis, on dependent parts of the body after death due to capillo-venous distension. Option D.Cataleptic rigidity- A group of voluntary muscles which are active & contracted at the moment of death. They continue to be in the same state of contraction, after death for a few hours.

questions.text: Worker in matchstick factory present with multiple discharge from sinuses on jaw. Which of the following is the likely poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phosphorus The above mentioned case is suggestive of chronic phosphorus poisoning. The patient has a phossy jaw , which refers to osteomyelitis and necrosis of jaw and foul smelling pus discharge and multiple sinuses . Initially, this condition presents with toothache , followed by jaw swelling, loosening of teeth . Later on this progresses to osteomyelitis .

Highyeild:

Phosphorus in a non metal , irritant poison which is found in two states: White phosphorus ( toxic form) Red phosphorus ( non toxic form) Highly toxic Highly inflammable (stored in water) Luminescent Garlicky odour Non toxic Signs and symptoms include garlic odour, luminous vomit and stool, liver necrosis , fatty liver and smoky stool syndrome (fumes from the stool). ACUTE PHOSPHORUS POISONING- Clinical Feature : Breath/ Vomitus /Excreta Garlicky smell Vomitus and excreta – luminescent → SMOKY STOOl SYNDROME The diagnostic feature- HAEMORRHAGIC SYNDROME : Haematemesis Hematuria Haemorrhage into skin, mucous membrane & parenchyma of organs. HEPATOTOXICITY: Foetor Hepaticus Flapping tremors of hands Hepatic Encephalopathy Treatment : 2% CuSO4 solution as lavage solution, chemical antidote→Gastric lavage done with 1:5000 KMnO4→ Converts phosphorus into phosphonic acid and phosphates→ harmless . K 20 mg I.V used for hypoprothrombinemia. Post Mortem findings Gastric contents - Garlicky odour Luminescent Acute Yellow atrophy liver CHRONIC POISONING- Referred as “PHOSSY JAW” Phossy Jaw : chronic osteomyelitis of mandible with multiple sinuses discharging foul smelling fluid / pus. Disease is obsolete. Earlier Lucifer matches – strike anywhere matches used to have white phosphorus in the tip.Now, Safety matches are used – made of Potassium chlorate,Antimony sulphide Side of match box contains : Red phosphorus + Ground glass or powdered glass Medicolegal Importance- Accidental phosphorus poisoning – DIWALI POISONING Arson : White phosphorus + cow dung→ Thrown in roof of huts in village → Roof contains dry grass → Cow dung once dried acts as catalyst and Immediately catches fire.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Antimony toxicity occurs either due to occupational exposure or during therapy . Occupational exposure may cause respiratory irritation, pneumoconiosis, antimony spots on the skin and gastrointestinal symptoms . In addition antimony trioxide is possibly carcinogenic to humans. Option C. Lead is the most common chronic heavy metal poisoning. Signs and symptoms include Burtonian lines along gums, nocturnal spasmodic abdominal pain, wrist drop and foot drop, irreversible brain damage in children and lead osteopathy - radiopaque bands along metaphysis. Option D. Cadmium causes nephrotoxicity and ouch disease (ita-ita). Signs and symptoms include golden yellow staining of teeth, bone pains, osteomalacia and waddling gait.

questions.text: Hooch tragedy was due to consumption of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methyl alcohol The Hooch tragedy was due to consumption of wood alcohol( methanol) . Signs and symptoms are due to accumulation of formic acid, the end metabolite of methanol. These include severe metabolic acidosis and blindness. Management includes ethanol, bicarbonate, 4-methyl pyrazole, folinic acid and hemodialysis.

Highyeild:

Alcohol Congener→ responsible for any flavor in beverage and hangover effect. State Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) mg% State of excitement 50-150 State of Incoordination 150-250 State of Coma >300 Medicolegally Permissible BAC under Motor vehicle act 30 Under the influence of alcohol 80-150 Intoxicated >150 Clinical features- LAteral gaze nystagmus→ elicited in excitement state Mc ewan’s sign → coma state Pupils would be in constricted state, upon painful stimulation constricted pupils dilate slowly, dilate completely and again return to constricted state. Treatment- Gastric lavage Coma cocktail: 100 ml 50% dextrose 100 mg thiamin 2mg naloxone Hemodialysis Investigation: Best: gas chromatography→legally accepted Breath analyzer : works on henry’s principle→ Concentration of alcohol in 1 ml of blood is same as 2100 ml of alveolar area. Medicolegal importance- Section 185 motor vehicle act Drunken driving Permissible BAC: 30 mg% Punishment→ 1st offence: imprisonment of 6 months or fine 10,000. Subsequent offence: Imprisonment of 2 years or fine of 15,000 510 IPC: misconduct of drunken person in public→ imprisonment for 24 hours. Delirium tremens: Alcohol withdrawal syndrome Now accepted as acute attack of Insanity → sec. 84 IPC Mc Naughten rule Methyl alcohol: Treatment of choice:Ethyl alcohol Hemodialysis (First option).

questions.text: Injury with crushing of hair bulb is noted. Identify the injury?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Split laceration Injury with crushing of hair bulb on head is suggestive of A Split laceration.

Highyeild:

Split Laceration- Also called as incised looking laceration Split lacerations are caused by blunt force splitting the thickness of the skin most frequently when the skin and soft tissues are crushed between impacting force and underlying bone. These types of lacerations are usually found in body parts with underlying bones without much tissue in between. Common sites include – scalp , face, shin etc. Due to splitting of skin these lacerations appear like incised wounds.

Avulsed Laceration - It is seen in runover injuries where shearing force is delivered at an oblique angle to the skin . Option D. Stab wound-Stab wound is produced from penetrating weapons with pointed ends. Depth is the maximum dimension in a stab wound.

questions.text: Identify the finding given in the image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pressure Abrasion In hanging, The force causing the abrasion is perpendicular to skin and exerted for a long time.Smaller force exerted for a long time causing Pressure abrasion.

Highyeild:

Abrasions are injuries in which there is destruction of skin involving only the superficial layers of epidermis. Mechanism: Caused when there is lateral friction of skin against rough surface. Simple injuries which bleed less, heal rapidly without any formation of scars. Types : 4 types Scratch Graze Pressure Imprint Scratch : Scratch is a linear abrasion which has a significant length and insignificant breadth /width. Very superficial incised wounds. Eg: Fingernail scratch Graze : C type of abrasion C type of abrasion in RTA Produced when a larger area of skin is frictioned against a large rough surface. Eg : Body is dragged along road Multiple small linear abrasions, tip of these abrasions have epidermal skin Indicates direction of force. Pressure Abrasions: The force causing the abrasion is perpendicular to skin and exerted for a long Smaller force exerted for a long time. Eg : ligature mark, bite marks Imprint / Impact Abrasions : They are produced when a larger force is applied perpendicular to the skin for a short interval (momentarily). Eg : Tyre marks, marks of radiator grill,headlamp Age of Abrasion- Fresh – Bright red 12 – 24 hrs – Bright red scab 2 – 3 days – Reddish brown scab 4 – 7 days – Brownish black scab >7 days – Scab falls – Depigmented area.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B.Imprint Abrasion- produced when a larger force is applied perpendicular to the skin for a short interval (momentarily). Option C.Scratch Abrasion- is a linear abrasion which has a significant length and insignificant breadth /width. Option D.Graze Abrasion- Produced when a larger area of skin is frictioned against a large rough surface.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 3 are true Among the given options Curren’s rule and Durham’s rule are associated with insanity.

Statement 3.Durham’s rule states that an accused is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the result of a mental disease or defect.

questions.text: Snake bite, management includes: Loose tourniquet Debride to avoid spread Identify and kill the snake Hospitalize for antivenom administration Immobilisation Which of the following options are correct:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4 and 5 The management of snakebite includes immobilisation and hospitalisation for antivenom administration.Immobilisation is done to prevent the spread of venom. Hospitalisations and antivenom administration is the definitive management of snake bite.

Highyeild:

Treatment of snake bite- Counselling the patient and family- Reassuring them that not all snakes are poisonous. Prevention of spread of venom- clean the bite area, Immobilise the patient Use of antivenom therapy- In India polyvalent ASV is only available It is effective against all the four common species; Russells viper (Daboia russelli), Common Cobra (raja naja) Common Krait (Bungarus caeruleus) Saw Scaled viper (Echis carinatus). ASV is the mainstay of treatment. It is lypohilised e. freeze dried and reconstituted . Sensitivity testing should be done by injecting 1 ml intradermally. given within 4hr of bite. Treatment of absorbed venom- Neurotoxic envenomation: ‘Atropine Neostigmine (AN) ’effective for postsynaptic neurotoxins such as those of the Krait affects presynaptic fibres where calcium ions act as neurotransmitters. Give Calcium gluconate and continue till neuroparalysis recovers which may last for 5-7 days. Viper bite -Give heparin and fibrinogen . symptomatic and general treatment- TT,antihistamines,analgesic, artificial respiration, hemodialysis.

questions.text: A lady underwent a cholecystectomy and now she presents with abdominal pain, one month later. Erect abdomen X-ray abdomen was taken and the image is given below. The following offence comes under?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Res ipsa loquitur Pair of surgical scissors left behind in the abdomen after surgery . The offence comes under res ipsa loquitur .

Highyeild:

Res ipsa loquitur- In doctrine of Res ipsa loquitur , the facts of the case are sufficient to justify the conclusion that doctor was negligent and negligence of doctor is responsible for the harm suffered by the patient. Examples of Res ipsa loquitur are as follows: Amputation of wrong digit or limb Leaving a swab or instrument in the abdomen of the patient after operation. Giving medicine carelessly or prescribing overdose of medicines produces ill effects. "Res ipsa loquitur" means "the thing or fact speaks for itself." The negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence . This doctrine applies to both civil and criminal negligence.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Res judicata -If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided in court , the patient will not be allowed to contest the same in another court based Multiple appeals cannot be made. Option C. Novus actus interveniens -It means an unrelated action intervening At times, it occurred that patients might suffer damage or harm due to new action , which intervene or intercede the For example – suppose an operated patient is shifted to a recovery room and suddenly, due to an earthquake , the ceiling falls over the patient and the patient dies in the accident. Here the falling of the ceiling is a new intervention that has occurred. A doctor may not be held responsible if damage occurred to a patient due to new action, which intervenes in the treatment. Option D. The principle of respondeat superior- says that the employer is responsible for employees negligence .

questions.text: A piece of cloth was submitted by police obtained from a crime scene with some dried stains. On microscopic examination after adding of picric acid solution, yellow needle shaped crystals are seen. This test is done to detect which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Semen Yellow needle crystals are seen in Barberio’s test . The test which the police did is the Barberio’s test , a commonly used test for semen analysis other than Florence test. In a Positive barberios test , the presence of spermine in the seminal sample is giving the yellow coloured needle crystals.

Highyeild:

Seminal Stains- Tests broadly divided into Chemical Tests: Acid Phosphatase Barberio’s Creatine Phosphokinase Florence Prostate specific antigen (PSA, P30) Microscopic Examination Chemical tests a. Acid phosphatase test - Secreted by prostate (prostatic epithelial cells) Activity of Acid phosphatase test in human semen is 500 – 1000 times greater than in any other body fluid. Normal acid phosphatase test activity in human semen is 340 – 360 Bodansky units per ml of semen. Concentration > 100 Bodansky units indicates that ejaculation occurred within 12 hours of examination Positive reactions are found upto 36 hrs after ejaculation in vaginal secretions. Acid phosphatase test – conclusive test in the absence of demonstrable sperm b. Barberio’s Test- Test / reaction depends on presence of spermine which comes from prostate Reaction gives a yellow, needle shaped, rhombic crystal of spermine picrate. C. Creatine Phosphokinase (CPK) Test - CPK – found both in spermatozoa and seminal ,plasma Normal seminal fluid contains , 385 -1400 units of CPK per ml Levels > 400 units are diagnostic of seminal stains The enzyme is stable and can be demonstrated in old stains of 6 months. d. Florence Test - Tests depend on the presence of choline in semen which comes from seminal vesicles. Choline is responsible for bluish – white fluorescence of seminal stains under UV light. Positive test gives dark brown, rhombic or needle shaped crystals of choline iodide, which resemble hemin crystals. This test is not specific for semen, as several substances of animal and vegetable origin give positive results. e. Prostate specific Antigen - PSA/ P30 - A glycoprotein produced by prostatic epithelial cells Detection of PSA – reliable indicator of semen Useful indicator in Azoospermia Microscopic Examination : The only absolute proof of semen is the microscope detection of at least one unbroken sperm. Complete sperms are seen upto 26 hrs in vagina, in the living, after ejaculation. After 26 hrs, they separate into head and tail. Similarly, after death complete sperms may be found upto 2 days in vagina and upto one week in the cervix & uterus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.CSF-Cerebrospinal fluid can be used to determine ethanol content at the time of death. Option C.Saliva- is used as biological evidence and is very helpful in determining various aspects of an individual such as sex, individuality, ABO blood groups, microbial signature, biomarkers, or habits like smoking. Option D.Blood- will show brown, rhombic (Teichmann’s test) OR pink,feathery crystal (takayama test).

Extraedge:

Red stain: Luminol spray test (high sensitivity)- test of choice Spectroscopy (high specificity)- Most reliable test White stain: UV light Gold standard: presence of intact sperm under microscope (stain-christmas tree). Azoospermia-raised levels of Prostate specific antigen (P 30) + acid phosphatase.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the act of a 40-year-old woman who feigned pregnancy, gave birth, and later presented a neighbor's child as her in an attempt to extort him for property advantages?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Suppositious child "Supposititious child" is a legal term used to refer to a child who is fraudulently represented as someone else's biological child . In other words, it is a child who is falsely claimed to be someone else's offspring. This can occur in cases of adoption fraud , where a child is presented as the biological child of the adoptive parents or in cases where a child is falsely claimed to be the biological child of someone else for various reasons such as inheritance or legal benefits.

Highyeild:

Superfecundation (1 cycle, 2 oocytes): occurs when two different ova are fertilized by two different sperm in more than one act of coitus during the same cycle. They are of the same gestational age. Superfetation (2 cycles, 2 oocytes) :occurs when a second fertilized ovum implants in a uterus already containing a pregnancy of at least 1 month. Superfetation has been suggested in some cases in which the twins are markedly discordant for birth weight, supposedly due to different gestational ages. Suppositious child : is a spurious child produced for inheritance claims or other malicious reasons . Posthumous child : is a child born after the death of the father . To be legitimate the child should be born within 280 days of the death of the father. Pseudocyesis/ spurious pregnancy/ Phantom pregnancy/False pregnancy :Intense desire for pregnancy by a married person → starts experiencing symptoms suggestive of pregnancy (Amenorrhoea, Bloating of abdomen , quickening movements).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Posthumous child is one who is born after the death of father Option C. Superfetation : Fertilisation of 2 ova in different ovulatory cycle Option D. Superfecundation : Fertilisation of 2 ova in same ovulatory cycle
